question:
Who gave the expanding universe hypothesis?

SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Evening)
solution:
• Edwin Hubble is credited with proposing the expanding universe hypothesis based on his observations in the 1920s.
  • He discovered that galaxies are moving away from us, and the farther a galaxy is, the faster it is receding, known as Hubble's Law.
  • This led to the conclusion that the universe is expanding, which became a foundational concept in modern cosmology.
  • His findings supported the Big Bang Theory, which suggests that the universe originated from a single point.

Additional Information:

  • Galileo Galilei: Known for contributions to telescope development and supporting heliocentrism.
  • James Clerk Maxwell: Formulated the classical theory of electromagnetic radiation.
  • C.V. Raman: Discovered the Raman Effect in light scattering, earning the Nobel Prize in Physics (1930).

question:
Geoid is the ________ of earth.

SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
The term Geoid refers to the shape of the Earth.

It is the most accurate representation of Earth's mean sea level, extended continuously through the continents.

The Geoid is an irregular, but uniquely defined shape that represents the surface where gravity is equal everywhere.

It differs slightly from a perfect sphere or even an ellipsoid due to variations in Earth's gravitational field.

Hence, the correct answer is shape.

Additional Information:

  • The Earth is not a perfect sphere; it's slightly flattened at the poles and bulging at the equator — this shape is called an oblate spheroid.
  • The Geoid takes this one step further by accounting for gravitational anomalies (like mountains or ocean trenches).

question:
Which is, by far, the closest dwarf planet orbiting at only 2.8 times Earth’s distance from the sun?

SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Ceres is the closest dwarf planet to the Sun, located in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter.
  • It orbits the Sun at a distance of about 8 AU (Astronomical Units), where 1 AU is the average distance between the Earth and the Sun.
  • It was the first dwarf planet to be discovered (in 1801) and is the only dwarf planet located in the inner solar system.
  • Other dwarf planets like Pluto, Eris, and Makemake are much farther out, residing in the Kuiper Belt.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Ceres.

Additional Information:

  • Pluto: Orbits at ~39 AU from the Sun.
  • Eris: Farther than Pluto, about ~68 AU.
  • Makemake: Orbits at ~45.8 AU.

question:
A ________ is a cloud of dust and gas inside a galaxy.

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• A nebula is a large cloud of gas and dust found in space, often inside galaxies.
  • Nebulae are the birthplaces of stars — regions where new stars are formed due to the gravitational collapse of gas.
  • They can also be remnants of dead stars, such as supernova remnants.
  • Nebulae often appear as bright or dark patches in the night sky and are visible through telescopes.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is nebula.

Additional Information:

  • Black Hole: A region in space with intense gravity from which nothing can escape, not a gas cloud.
  • Photosphere: The visible surface of the Sun, not a cloud.
  • Chromosphere: A thin layer above the Sun’s photosphere, also not a cloud of dust and gas.

question:
A distinctive cross- shaped constellation best seen in the northern hemisphere during the summer and fall months around September is:

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• Cygnus is a distinctive cross-shaped constellation, also known as the Northern Cross.
  • It is best visible in the northern hemisphere during the summer and fall months, especially around September.
  • The constellation represents a swan in flight across the Milky Way.
  • Its brightest star is Deneb, which forms part of the Summer Triangle along with Vega and Altair.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Cygnus.

Additional Information:

  • Ursa Major: Best known for the Big Dipper asterism, visible year-round in the northern sky.
  • Pegasus: Recognized for the Great Square, more visible in fall but not cross-shaped.
  • Cassiopeia: W-shaped constellation, visible in the northern sky year-round.

question:
The colour of the surface of Mars is red because of the presence of large amounts of chemical compounds in it. What is the name of that compound ?

SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The red colour of Mars is due to the presence of Iron Oxide (Fe₂O₃) on its surface.
  • Iron oxide is commonly known as rust, and it gives the Martian soil its distinct reddish appearance.
  • This is why Mars is often referred to as the "Red Planet".
  • The surface dust and rocks contain oxidized iron, which reflects sunlight in a way that appears red to observers.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Iron Oxide.

Additional Information:

  • Magnesium oxide: A white compound, not responsible for any red coloration.
  • Tin oxide: Used in ceramics and glass, not found significantly on Mars.
  • Nitrogen oxide: A gas, not responsible for surface coloration.

question:
Which dwarf planet orbits the sun in 310 years at a distance between 38.5 to 53 AU?

SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• Makemake is a dwarf planet located in the Kuiper Belt, a region beyond Neptune.
  • It orbits the Sun at a distance of approximately 5 to 53 AU (Astronomical Units).
  • Its orbital period is about 310 Earth years, which matches the given data in the question.
  • Pluto takes around 248 years to orbit and ranges between 29 to 49 AU, so it's incorrect.
  • Eris orbits in 557 years and at a greater distance, hence also incorrect.
  • Ceres lies in the asteroid belt and completes an orbit in just 4.6 years, so it's not the answer.

Additional Information:

  • Makemake was discovered in 2005.
  • It is one of the five officially recognized dwarf planets by the IAU.
  • It is smaller than Pluto but larger than Ceres and has no significant atmosphere.

question:
Which of the following is the second nearest star to Earth?

SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• Proxima Centauri is the closest star to Earth after the Sun, located approximately 24 light years away.
  • The second nearest star system is Alpha Centauri, which includes Proxima Centauri as part of a triple star system.
  • While technically Sirius and others are visible and bright, they are farther from Earth:
    • Sirius: ~8.6 light years away
    • Polaris (North Star): ~433 light years away
    • Delta Velorum: ~80.6 light years away
  • Thus, Proxima Centauri is still considered the second nearest starafter the Sun (if the Sun is taken as the first).

Additional Information:

  • Proxima Centauri is a red dwarf star.
  • It has at least two exoplanets, one of which is in the habitable zone.
  • Located in the constellation Centaurus.

question:
Which of the following statements most accurately describes the planet Saturn?

SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: It is a gas giant made up mostly of hydrogen and helium and the density is less than that of water
option_2: Its surface is reddish in colour.
option_3: It was the seventh planet discovered in the Solar System.
option_4: Its cloud-like outer regions consist of methane in the gaseous form and ammonia in crystalline form.
solution:
• Saturn is a gas giant, composed primarily of hydrogen and helium, just like Jupiter.
  • Its average density is less than that of water (around 687 g/cm³), making it the least dense planet in the Solar System — it could float in water.
  • Option (b) describes Mars, known for its reddish surface due to iron oxide.
  • Option (c) is incorrect — Saturn was known since ancient times and is visible to the naked eye.
  • Option (d) partly fits Uranus and Neptune, not Saturn — methane is more dominant in those planets.

Additional Information:

  • Saturn’s rings are the most extensive and visible in the Solar System.
  • It has more than 140 moons, with Titan being the largest and second biggest in the Solar System.
  • A year on Saturn is about 29.5 Earth years long.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a Moon of Jupiter ?

SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• Jupiter has 92 confirmed moons, with the four largest known as the Galilean moons:
    • Io,
    • Europa,
    • Ganymede,
    • Callisto
  • All three options (a) Callisto, (b) Europa, and (c) Ganymede are among Jupiter’s major moons.
  • Triton, option (d), is not a moon of Jupiter — it is the largest moon of Neptune.
  • Triton is unique for its retrograde orbit, suggesting it may be a captured object.

Additional Information:

  • Ganymede is the largest moon in the Solar System — even bigger than Mercury.
  • Europa is believed to have a subsurface ocean and is a prime candidate in the search for extraterrestrial life.
  • Callisto is the most heavily cratered object in the Solar System.

question:
Which of the following rocky planets is the fastest planet in our solar system– traveling through space at about 29 miles (47 kilometers) per second?

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• Mercury is the innermost planet in our solar system and also the fastest orbiting planet.
  • It travels around the Sun at an average speed of about 47 km/second (29 miles/second).
  • This high speed is due to its proximity to the Sun — gravitational pull is stronger, so orbital speed is higher.
  • Earth moves at about 30 km/second, Venus at around 35 km/second, and Mars even slower (~24 km/second).
  • Hence, none of the other rocky (terrestrial) planets match Mercury’s speed.

Additional Information:

  • A year on Mercury is only about 88 Earth days long.
  • Mercury does not have an atmosphere to slow it down significantly.
  • Despite being closest to the Sun, Mercury is not the hottest planet — Venus holds that title due to its thick greenhouse atmosphere.

question:
Which of the following planets’ atmosphere is made up of thick white and yellowish clouds of sulphuric acid ?

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Venus has a dense atmosphere composed mostly of carbon dioxide, with thick clouds of sulphuric acid.
  • These white and yellowish clouds are made of sulphuric acid droplets, which reflect sunlight and make Venus very bright in the sky.
  • The atmospheric pressure on Venus is about 92 times that of Earth, and the planet has a strong greenhouse effect, making it the hottest planet in the Solar System.
  • The other options do not match:
    • Jupiter: Atmosphere mostly of hydrogen and helium.
    • Mars: Thin CO₂ atmosphere with reddish dust, no sulphuric acid clouds.
    • Neptune: Methane-rich atmosphere, blue color, no sulphuric acid clouds.

Additional Information:

  • Venus’s clouds are highly reflective, contributing to its nickname: “Earth’s twin” in brightness, though not in environment.
  • Surface temperatures on Venus reach up to 465°C — hotter than Mercury.

question:
Which of the following is one of the largest spiral galaxies?

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• NGC 6872 is one of the largest known spiral galaxies in the universe.
  • It spans over 522,000 light-years, making it more than 5 times larger than the Milky Way.
  • It has a barred spiral structure and is located in the constellation Pavo.
  • The other options do not qualify:
    • Milky Way: A spiral galaxy, but not the largest.
    • Cygnus A: It is a radio galaxy, not a spiral one.
    • Maffei 1: It is an elliptical galaxy, not spiral.

Additional Information:

  • NGC 6872 is also known as Condor Galaxy.
  • It is interacting gravitationally with a nearby galaxy called IC 4970, which may contribute to its extended shape.
  • Spiral galaxies are characterized by their arms winding out from the center.

question:
The length of a day on ______ is approximately 16 hours.

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• A day on a planet refers to the time it takes to complete one full rotation on its axis.
  • Neptune completes one rotation in approximately 16 hours, making it one of the planets with the shortest days in the solar system.
  • Let’s evaluate other options:
    • Venus: Has an extremely slow rotation — one day is about 243 Earth days, and it rotates retrograde (opposite direction).
    • Mercury: Takes about 59 Earth days for one rotation.
    • Mars: Has a rotation period similar to Earth — around 6 hours.

Additional Information:

  • Neptune is the eighth and farthest planet from the Sun.
  • Its fast rotation causes a noticeable bulge at the equator.
  • Despite its distance, it has strongest winds in the solar system — up to 2,100 km/h.

question:
Who was the first to develop a mathematical predictive heliocentric model of the solar system ?

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• Nicolaus Copernicus was the first to develop a mathematical, predictive, heliocentric model of the solar system in the 16th century.
  • In his model, the Sun is placed at the center, and the Earth and other planets revolve around it — a revolutionary idea at the time.
  • This challenged the long-accepted geocentric (Earth-centered) model by Ptolemy.
  • His major work, "De revolutionibus orbium coelestium" (1543), laid the foundation for modern astronomy.
  • Other options:
    • Galileo Galilei supported the heliocentric theory but came later and improved observational proof through telescopes.
    • Laplace and Immanuel Kant worked on cosmological models, not the first heliocentric system.

Additional Information:

  • Copernicus’s model introduced the idea of planetary retrograde motion as an optical illusion due to Earth's movement.
  • His heliocentric theory triggered the Scientific Revolution and inspired astronomers like Kepler and Newton.

question:
Who calculated the approximate location of the planet Neptune by studying gravity- induced disturbances in the motion of Uranus?

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• Urbain-Jean-Joseph Le Verrier, a French mathematician, calculated the approximate position of Neptune by studying irregularities in Uranus’s orbit.
  • These gravitational disturbances could not be explained by known planets, suggesting the presence of another unseen planet.
  • Le Verrier sent his calculations to Johann Gottfried Galle, who later observed Neptune in 1846 — exactly where Le Verrier predicted.
  • Although John Couch Adams (from England) made independent and similar calculations, Le Verrier’s prediction led directly to the actual discovery.

Additional Information:

  • Neptune was the first planet discovered by mathematical prediction rather than direct observation.
  • The discovery marked a major success for Newtonian mechanics and celestial mathematics.

question:
The point in the orbit of an object (such as a satellite) orbiting the earth that is at the greatest distance from the centre of the earth is known as:

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The terms perigee and apogee refer specifically to the Earth’s orbit:
    • Perigee: the point in the orbit where the object is closest to the Earth.
    • Apogee: the point in the orbit where the object is farthest from the Earth.
  • The question asks for the greatest distance from Earth’s center — hence, the correct answer is apogee.
  • Perihelion and aphelion refer to orbits around the Sun, not Earth:
    • Perihelion: closest to the Sun.
    • Aphelion: farthest from the Sun.

Additional Information:

  • Satellites in elliptical orbits have different speeds at apogee and perigee — they move slowest at apogee.
  • The concept applies to natural (Moon) and artificial satellites.

question:
A flat ring of small, icy bodies that revolve around the sun beyond the orbit of the planet Neptune is called:

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The Kuiper Belt is a flat, disc-shaped region beyond the orbit of Neptune, containing many small, icy bodies that orbit the Sun.
  • It is similar to the Asteroid Belt, but much larger and composed mostly of frozen volatiles like methane, ammonia, and water.
  • This belt includes dwarf planets like Pluto, Haumea, and Makemake.
  • Let’s clarify the incorrect options:
    • Oort Cloud: A distant spherical shell of icy objects, much farther than the Kuiper Belt.
    • Bow Shock: Related to solar wind interactions, not a region of icy bodies.
    • Asteroid Belt: Lies between Mars and Jupiter, made of rocky debris, not icy bodies.

Additional Information:

  • The Kuiper Belt extends from about 30 AU to 50 AU from the Sun.
  • It is considered the source of many short-period comets (those with orbits less than 200 years).

question:
The Big Dipper is an asterism formed by the seven brightest stars in the constellation:

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• The Big Dipper is an asterism, meaning a recognizable pattern of stars, not a full constellation.
  • It is made up of the seven brightest stars in the constellation Ursa Major (also known as the Great Bear).
  • The Big Dipper resembles a ladle or plough and is one of the most easily recognizable star patterns in the northern sky.
  • Clarifying other options:
    • Cassiopeia: Shaped like a "W", not related to the Big Dipper.
    • Leo Major: Incorrect term — the correct constellation is Leo.
    • Orion: Famous for Orion’s Belt, not associated with the Big Dipper.

Additional Information:

  • Two stars at the end of the Big Dipper’s bowl — Dubhe and Merak — are called the “pointer stars”, as they point to Polaris (North Star).
  • The Big Dipper is often used in navigation in the Northern Hemisphere.

question:
A constellation of the northern sky easily recognised by a group of five bright stars forming a slightly irregular ‘W’ is called:

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The constellation Cassiopeia is one of the most easily recognizable patterns in the northern sky.
  • It is identified by five bright stars that form a slightly irregular ‘W’ shape.
  • Named after Queen Cassiopeia from Greek mythology, this constellation is circumpolar (visible year-round in northern latitudes).
  • Other options:
    • Orion: Recognized by the three-star belt — not W-shaped.
    • Ursa Major: Known for the Big Dipper pattern — more like a ladle.
    • Cygnus: Known as the Northern Cross — cross-shaped, not W-shaped.

Additional Information:

  • Cassiopeia is located opposite Ursa Major across the North Star (Polaris).
  • It is used in celestial navigation due to its distinct shape and year-round visibility in the north.

question:
Which planet is the second largest planet in our solar system and also has the biggest and the brightest rings around it ?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Saturn is the second largest planet in our solar system after Jupiter
  • It is a gas giant composed mostly of hydrogen and helium
  • Saturn is famous for its bright, extensive ring system, which is made of ice particles, rocks, and dust
  • The rings are the largest and most visible compared to those of other planets
  • Though Jupiter, Uranus, and Neptune also have rings, they are faint and not as prominent

Additional Information:

  • Saturn has 83 confirmed moons, with Titan being the largest
  • It takes about 5 Earth years to complete one orbit around the Sun
  • Its density is so low that it would float on water

question:
_________ oblong orbit overlaps the orbit of Neptune.

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Pluto follows a highly elliptical (oblong) orbit, unlike the near-circular orbits of the major planets
  • At certain points in its orbit, Pluto comes closer to the Sun than Neptune, causing its orbit to overlap Neptune’s orbit
  • This overlapping, however, does not lead to collision because of a 1:2 orbital resonance with Neptune – Pluto completes 2 orbits for every 3 of Neptune
  • This gravitational relationship prevents them from ever colliding, despite the overlap

Additional Information:

  • Pluto was considered the ninth planet until 2006, after which it was reclassified as a dwarf planet by the IAU
  • Its orbit is inclined and eccentric compared to the 8 classical planets
  • Pluto takes about 248 Earth years to complete one orbit around the Sun

question:
Which of the following statements about planet Saturn is true?

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (1st shift)
option_1: Saturn is the fourth planet from the Sun and the largest planet in our solar system.
option_2: Satellites like Enceladus and Titan of Saturn are home to internal oceans, could possibly support life.
option_3: Saturn's environment is conducive to life.
option_4: Saturn is a massive ball made up mostly nitrogen.
solution:
• Saturn’s moons Enceladus and Titan are of great interest to scientists due to the presence of internal oceans beneath their icy crusts.
  • These subsurface oceans may contain the chemical ingredients necessary for life, making them potential candidates for hosting microbial life.
  • NASA’s Cassini mission provided strong evidence of water plumes on Enceladus and organic compounds on Titan.
  • Therefore, option (b) is the correct and scientifically accurate statement.

Additional Information:

  • Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun, not the fourth.
  • It is primarily made of hydrogen and helium, not nitrogen.
  • The planet itself has extreme temperatures and pressures, making it inhospitable for life.

question:
Which star is also known as the ‘Pole Star’ ?

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• The Pole Star is also known as the North Star or Polaris.
  • It is located almost directly above Earth’s North Pole, making it appear nearly stationary in the sky.
  • Because of this, it has been used for navigation for centuries, especially by sailors.
  • It lies in the constellation Ursa Minor, at the end of the Little Dipper’s handle.
  • The other directional stars like East, West, or South stars do not exist as fixed reference points.

Additional Information:

  • Polaris is approximately 433 light-years away from Earth.
  • Its position makes it a reliable indicator of true north in the night sky.
  • In the Southern Hemisphere, there is no equivalent bright Pole Star.

question:
In 1905, who concluded with Thomas Chamberlain that the planets of the Solar System originated from an encounter between the Sun and another star?

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• In 1905, Forest Ray Moulton, an American astronomer, proposed a theory along with Thomas C. Chamberlain called the Chamberlain-Moulton Planetary Hypothesis.
  • According to this theory, the planets of the solar system formed due to material pulled out of the Sun when a passing star came near it, creating tidal effects.
  • This encounter hypothesis was an early attempt to explain the origin of planets, though it was later replaced by more accepted theories like the Nebular Hypothesis.
  • The other scientists listed are associated with different fields:
    • James Hutton – known as the father of modern geology
    • Inge Lehmann – discovered Earth’s inner core
    • Charles Lyell – popularized uniformitarianism in geology

Additional Information:

  • The Chamberlain-Moulton theory emphasized stellar encounters, but was eventually discarded due to issues explaining angular momentum and rarity of such encounters.
  • Today, the Nebular Theory is the most widely accepted explanation for the formation of the solar system.

question:
Perihelion is when Earth is ______.

Graduate Level 24/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
option_2: farthest from the sun
option_3: nearest to the sun
solution:
• Perihelion is the point in the Earth's elliptical orbit where it is closest to the Sun.
  • It occurs around early January every year (usually between January 3–5).
  • The term comes from Greek: "peri" meaning near and "helios" meaning Sun.
  • In contrast, Aphelion is when the Earth is farthest from the Sun, occurring around early July.
  • Despite being closer to the Sun during perihelion, the Northern Hemisphere experiences winter, because the seasons are determined by Earth's axial tilt, not distance.

Additional Information:

  • Average distance during perihelion: about 147.1 million km
  • Average distance during aphelion: about 152.1 million km
  • Earth’s orbit is not a perfect circle but a slightly elliptical shape.

question:
Which is the most widely accepted model to explain the formation and evaluation of the solar system?

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The Nebular Hypothesis is the most widely accepted model to explain the formation and evolution of the solar system.
  • It was originally proposed by Immanuel Kant (1755) and later expanded by Pierre-Simon Laplace.
  • According to this hypothesis, the solar system formed from a large cloud of gas and dust (called a solar nebula) around 6 billion years ago.
  • Under the influence of gravity, this cloud collapsed and spun, forming the Sun at the center and planets from the remaining material.
  • The planets, moons, and other bodies formed through a process of accretion — where particles collided and stuck together.

Additional Information:

  • The gas and cloud hypotheses are earlier, less detailed ideas and are now considered outdated.
  • The solar hypothesis is a generic term and lacks the specific mechanisms provided in the nebular theory.
  • Modern refinements to the nebular hypothesis include concepts like protoplanetary disks and planetary migration.

question:
Terrestrial planets are composed of _______.

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Terrestrial planets are the inner planets of the solar system: Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars.
  • They are called "terrestrial" because they have a solid, rocky surface similar to Earth.
  • These planets are primarily composed of rocks and metals, especially silicates and iron.
  • Unlike gas giants, they have smaller sizes, higher densities, and thin or no atmospheres.
  • Their solid surfaces allow for features like mountains, craters, and volcanoes.

Additional Information:

  • Terrestrial planets have a metallic core, a rocky mantle, and a solid crust.
  • They rotate slowly and have fewer or no moons compared to gas giants.
  • Earth is the largest terrestrial planet and the only one known to support life.

question:
Which trend is found about the distance between the galaxies?

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Observations by Edwin Hubble in the 1920s showed that galaxies are moving away from each other.
  • This discovery led to the concept of an expanding universe, which is a key foundation of the Big Bang Theory.
  • The redshift in light from distant galaxies indicates that their distance from Earth is increasing over time.
  • This trend is uniform, meaning galaxies are receding in all directions, implying space itself is expanding.
  • Hence, the distance between galaxies is increasing, not constant, decreasing, or unpredictable.

Additional Information:

  • The Hubble’s Law quantifies this expansion: velocity of recession ∝ distance.
  • The farther a galaxy is, the faster it is moving away.
  • This expanding nature of the universe is supported by cosmic microwave background radiation and modern telescopic data.

question:
On which planet has a rotating oval of clouds, twice as wide as Earth, called the 'Great Red Spot' been observed for more than 300 years ?

SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Great Red Spot is a massive, rotating storm system observed on the planet Jupiter.
  • It is an oval-shaped anticyclonic storm that has persisted for over 300 years, possibly even longer.
  • The storm is so large that it is approximately twice the width of Earth.
  • It rotates counterclockwise and is located in Jupiter’s southern hemisphere.
  • The reddish color is likely due to chemical reactions involving the planet’s atmosphere and solar radiation.

Additional Information:

  • The Great Red Spot was first observed by astronomers in the 17th century.
  • Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system and is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium.
  • The planet has a thick atmosphere with multiple storm systems, but the Great Red Spot is the most prominent.

question:
Which scientist thought of the concept of the steady state of the universe?

SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The steady state theory of the universe was proposed by Fred Hoyle, along with Hermann Bondi and Thomas Gold in 1948.
  • According to this theory, the universe is eternal and unchanging in its large-scale structure, despite expanding.
  • It suggests that as the universe expands, new matter is continuously created, so that the overall density remains constant.
  • This idea was an alternative to the Big Bang Theory, which proposes that the universe had a definite beginning.
  • The steady state theory lost support after the discovery of the cosmic microwave background radiation in 1965, which strongly supported the Big Bang model.

Additional Information:

  • Fred Hoyle also coined the term “Big Bang,” ironically, while criticizing the theory.
  • Edwin Hubble is known for discovering the expansion of the universe.
  • Harold Jeffrey was a geophysicist and mathematician, not associated with this theory.
  • Pierre-Simon Laplace worked on celestial mechanics and the nebular hypothesis, not cosmology.

question:
Cosmic snowballs of frozen gases, rock and dust that orbit the Sun are known as_______.

SSC MTS 16/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Comets are often described as "cosmic snowballs" made of frozen gases, rock, and dust.
  • They orbit the Sun in long, elliptical paths and are part of our solar system.
  • When a comet approaches the Sun, the heat causes its ice to vaporize, forming a glowing coma and a tail that always points away from the Sun due to the solar wind.
  • Comets typically originate from the Kuiper Belt or Oort Cloud, which are distant regions of icy bodies beyond Neptune.

Additional Information:

  • Meteors are space rocks that burn upon entering Earth's atmosphere (also called "shooting stars").
  • Meteorites are the parts of meteors that survive and land on Earth.
  • A star is a massive ball of gas, like our Sun, not a frozen body.

question:
What is the radius of the earth?

SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The average radius of the Earth is approximately 6371 kilometers.
  • This value represents the mean radius, as Earth is not a perfect sphere but an oblate spheroid — slightly flattened at the poles and bulging at the equator.
  • The equatorial radius is about 6378 km, while the polar radius is around 6357 km.
  • Hence, 6371 km is accepted as the standard average radius for general scientific and exam purposes.

Additional Information:

  • The circumference of the Earth is approximately 40,075 km at the equator.
  • The surface area is about 510 million square kilometers, including both land and water.

question:
Each orbit of the International Space Station (ISS) takes _____minutes .

SSC CHSL 13/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The International Space Station (ISS) orbits Earth at an altitude of approximately 400 kilometers.
  • It travels at a speed of about 28,000 km/h, allowing it to complete one full orbit around Earth in approximately 90 to 93 minutes.
  • This means the ISS completes about 16 orbits per day, enabling astronauts to witness multiple sunrises and sunsets daily.
  • Its fast orbital period is due to its low Earth orbit (LEO) and lack of atmospheric drag at that altitude.

Additional Information:

  • The ISS is a joint project involving NASA, Roscosmos, ESA, JAXA, and CSA.
  • It has been continuously inhabited since November 2000 and serves as a space laboratory for scientific research.

question:
In approximately how much time does Mars complete one spin on its axis?

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Mars completes one full rotation on its axis (i.e., one Martian day) in approximately 6 hours.
  • This duration is very close to an Earth day, which is why Mars has similar day-night cycles.
  • The rotation period of Mars is referred to as a “sol”, which is only slightly longer than an Earth day.
  • Hence, the best approximate answer for Mars' spin duration is 1 day.

Additional Information:

  • A Martian year (one orbit around the Sun) takes about 687 Earth days.
  • Mars has two moons, Phobos and Deimos.
  • Its axial tilt is 25.2°, similar to Earth’s, which gives it seasonal variations.

question:
Which among the following is not a type of solar eclipse?

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• A solar eclipse occurs when the Moon comes between the Earth and the Sun, casting a shadow on Earth.
  • There are three main types of solar eclipses:
    1. Total Solar Eclipse – The Moon completely covers the Sun.
    2. Partial Solar Eclipse – The Moon covers only part of the Sun.
    3. Annular Solar Eclipse – The Moon covers the center of the Sun, leaving a “ring of fire” around it.
  • Penumbral eclipse is not a type of solar eclipse; it refers to a type of lunar eclipse where the Moon passes through the Earth’s penumbral (outer) shadow, causing a subtle darkening.

Additional Information:

  • In a penumbral lunar eclipse, the dimming is so slight that it is often hard to notice with the naked eye.
  • Solar eclipses can only occur during a new moon, whereas lunar eclipses occur during a full moon.
  • Annular eclipses happen when the Moon is too far from Earth to completely cover the Sun.

question:
In early 1610, who discovered with his newly invented telescope that Jupiter has four moons?

SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• In early 1610, Galileo Galilei used his newly improved telescope to observe Jupiter.
  • He discovered four large moons orbiting the planet, now known as the Galilean moons: Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto.
  • This discovery provided strong support for the heliocentric model, as it showed not everything revolves around Earth.
  • Galileo published his observations in "Sidereus Nuncius" (The Starry Messenger) in 1610.

Additional Information:

  • Though Simon Marius also observed Jupiter's moons around the same time, Galileo is credited as the discoverer because he published first.
  • Tycho Brahe was a pre-telescopic astronomer known for his precise measurements.
  • Johannes Kepler developed the laws of planetary motion but did not discover Jupiter’s moons.

question:
Who was the first to accurately describe the rings of Saturn as a disc around the planet in 1655?

SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• In 1655, Christiaan Huygens, a Dutch astronomer and mathematician, was the first to accurately describe the rings of Saturn.
  • Using a more advanced telescope than Galileo’s, he observed that Saturn was surrounded by a thin, flat ring, which did not touch the planet.
  • This was a major improvement over Galileo Galilei's earlier observation in 1610, where he thought Saturn had “ears” or strange appendages due to his low-resolution telescope.
  • Huygens correctly proposed that the planet was surrounded by a ring-like disc, which explained its changing appearance.

Additional Information:

  • Giovanni Cassini later discovered that Saturn’s ring system is divided into multiple parts, including the well-known Cassini Division.
  • Hideki Yukawa was a Japanese physicist known for his work in nuclear physics, not astronomy.
  • Galileo first saw the rings but couldn’t interpret them accurately.

question:
The moon completes _________ rotation on its axis as it completes one revolution around the Earth.

SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The Moon completes exactly one rotation on its axis in the same amount of time it takes to complete one revolution around the Earth — about 3 days.
  • This synchronous movement is called synchronous rotation or tidal locking.
  • As a result, the same side of the Moon always faces Earth, while the far side remains mostly hidden from view.
  • This is why we always see only one hemisphere of the Moon from Earth.

Additional Information:

  • The Moon’s revolution and rotation are both counterclockwise when viewed from above the North Pole.
  • The hidden side of the Moon is called the "far side", not the "dark side" — as it also receives sunlight.

question:
Which of the following statements regarding the moon is correct?

I. The size of the illuminated part of the moon visible from the Earth increases each day after the new moon day.

II. After the full moon day, the sunlit part of the moon visible from the Earth decreases in size every day.

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)
option_1: Both I and II
option_3: Neither I nor II
solution:
• Statement I: After the new moon day, the illuminated part of the moon (as seen from Earth) gradually increases each night. This phase is known as the waxing phase, which leads up to the full moon. ✅
  • Statement II: After the full moon day, the visible sunlit portion starts decreasing each day. This is called the waning phase, which continues until the next new moon. ✅
  • Both statements correctly describe the lunar phases as observed from Earth.

Additional Information:

  • The complete lunar cycle (from new moon to new moon) takes about 5 days, known as a synodic month.
  • The primary phases of the Moon: New Moon → First Quarter → Full Moon → Last Quarter → New Moon.

question:
The ______ radiation belts are giant swaths of magnetically trapped highly energetic charged particles that surround Earth.

SSC CGL 13/04/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The correct answer is Van Allen radiation belts.
  • These are two giant doughnut-shaped zones of highly energetic charged particles (mainly electrons and protons) that are trapped by Earth’s magnetic field.
  • They were discovered in 1958 by James Van Allen using instruments aboard the Explorer 1 satellite.
  • These belts protect Earth by shielding it from harmful solar wind and cosmic rays.
  • The belts are located at altitudes of about 1,000–60,000 km above Earth’s surface.

Additional Information:

  • Aurora refers to natural light displays (like aurora borealis), not radiation belts.
  • Kuiper Belt is a region beyond Neptune filled with icy bodies and dwarf planets.
  • Chinook is a type of warm, dry wind, not related to space or radiation.

question:
In which of the following periods is the meteor shower named Quadrantids generally visible from Earth?

SSC MTS 20/10/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Quadrantids are a major annual meteor shower that occurs in early January each year.
  • They are usually visible from December 28 to January 12, with a sharp peak around January 3–4.
  • The shower is named after the now-obsolete constellation Quadrans Muralis, which used to lie between Boötes and Draco.
  • Quadrantids are known for producing bright fireballs and a high rate of meteors, though the peak is very brief.

Additional Information:

  • Unlike other showers with broad peaks, Quadrantids often last only a few hours at peak visibility.
  • Other major meteor showers:
    • Perseids in August
    • Geminids in December
    • Lyrids in April

question:
In which of the following months may the meteor shower named Lyrids be seen from Earth?

SSC MTS 20/10/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Lyrids meteor shower is one of the oldest known meteor showers, observed for over 2,700 years.
  • It is visible from Earth every year in April, typically between April 16 to April 25, with the peak occurring around April 22.
  • The meteors appear to radiate from the constellation Lyra, hence the name Lyrids.
  • Though not as intense as the Perseids or Geminids, Lyrids can produce bright and fast meteors, occasionally leaving persistent trains.

Additional Information:

  • The source of the Lyrids is the comet C/1861 G1 Thatcher.
  • Lyrids are known for their unexpected surges, where up to 100 meteors per hour have been recorded.

question:
How many degrees does the Earth rotate about its own axis in one hour?

SSC CGL 06/03/2020 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Earth completes one full rotation (360°) on its axis in 24 hours.
  • To find how many degrees it rotates in one hour, we divide:
  • Therefore, the Earth rotates 15 degrees every hour.

Additional Information:

  • This rotational speed is used in time zone calculations, where each time zone typically spans 15 degrees of longitude.
  • Earth rotates from west to east, which is why the Sun rises in the east and sets in the west.
